member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.BaseCollection`1
member.summary: An abstract class representing a standard collection of objects.
member.remarks:
This was designed as a point of convenience to take some of the annoyance out of inheriting a collection.
This class provides a simplified method of inheriting a basic SortedList collection. It holds no benefit over the System.Collections.Generic.SortedList object, which it uses internally.
This class overloads properties to retrieve or remove an item by its index as well as by its key. These are setup as protected methods so that the user can implement the collection however they see fit.
This class, like the other collection classes, implements the IEnumerable interface already to return an iterator interface for enumeration.

This collection is inherited from when a standard collection interface is desired. Several methods have been implmented, such as Remove.
This collection inherits from the BaseCollection object and just implements some of the functionality for you.

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.Internal.NamedObject
member.summary: Abstract Class representing a named object.
member.remarks: Classes inheriting from this object will have a name associated with it. This is handy when dealing with unique objects within a collection.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Internal.NamedObject.Equals(System.Object)
member.summary: Function to determine if this named object is the same as another named object.
member.returns: TRUE if equal, FALSE if not.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Internal.NamedObject.GetHashCode
member.summary: Function to return the hash code for this object.
member.remarks:
A hash code is used by dictionaries and hash tables to determine uniqueness of an object within those collections.
Hash values are related to their types, and as such should use one or more of its instance fields hash codes to build the hash code.
member.returns: A 32 bit integer representing the hash code.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Internal.NamedObject.ToString
member.summary: Function to return the string representation of this object.
member.returns: A string containing the name of the type and the name stored within the object.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Internal.NamedObject.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Constructor.
member.remarks:
Since the Name property is read-only, the name for an object must be passed to this constructor.
Typically it will be difficult to rename an object that resides in a collection with its name as the key, thus making the property writable would be counter-productive.
However, objects that descend from this object may choose to implement their own renaming scheme if they so choose.
Ensure that the name parameter has a non-null string or is not a zero-length string. Failing to do so will raise a ArgumentNullException.
member.exception: Thrown when the name parameter is NULL or a zero length string.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Internal.NamedObject.Name
member.summary: Read-only property to return the name of this object.
member.remarks: The name of an object need not be unique, however if it is used as a key value for a collection then it should be unique.
member.value: A string containing the name of this object.

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.IShaderRenderer
member.summary: Defines a shader used in the rendering process.
member.remarks: This defines the component of a shader that can be applied to the rendering of a scene.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.IShaderRenderer.GetDefinedConstants
member.summary: Function to retrieve the pre-defined constant parameters from a shader.
member.remarks:
A shader can contain pre-defined constant values that the library will update automatically. This is done to cut down on some redundant code that the user will typically always have to perform when calling a shader. For example, the user may have 3 shaders and each time a shader is used the current sprite image would have to be set by the user each time the image changed for each sprite. Additionally, passing the transformations (i.e. rotation, scaling and translation) to the shader is also more work than it needs to be.
To use this "default" functionality your shader will have to implement one of these constants:
Constant type and name Description
float4x4 _projectionMatrix The current projection matrix defined by the current Viewport. Use this to transform vertices in a vertex shader into screen space.
Texture _spriteImage This is the currently active image (at index 0 in the texture stage) for a given Sprite or series of sprites.
The constants are case sensitive and as such must be declared exactly as shown in the table above with the leading underscore character. If the constant is not named properly it will not be used as a default.
To test whether the default constants are available, check the return value of HasProjectionMatrix or HasSpriteImage and if these properties return TRUE, then the constant has been implemented.
This function is meant to be called internally by the shader.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.IShaderRenderer.GetDefinedParameter(GorgonLibrary.Graphics.PredefinedShaderConstants)
member.summary: Function to return the parameter associated with the predefiend constant.
member.remarks:
The function will return the associated parameter object for a given pre-defined constant. The constant should be defined in the shader as one of:
Constant type and name Description
float4x4 _projectionMatrix The current projection matrix defined by the current Viewport. Use this to transform vertices in a vertex shader into screen space.
Texture _spriteImage This is the currently active image (at index 0 in the texture stage) for a given Sprite or series of sprites.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.IShaderRenderer.Begin
member.summary: Function to begin the rendering with the shader.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.IShaderRenderer.Render(GorgonLibrary.Graphics.PrimitiveStyle,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Function to render with the shader.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.IShaderRenderer.End
member.summary: Function to end rendering with the shader.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.IShaderRenderer.HasProjectionMatrix
member.summary: Property to return whether a projection matrix is available in the shader.
member.remarks:
This shader constant should be represented in the shader as: float4x4 _projectionMatrix. If this constant is found, this value will return TRUE.
If this is available the library will automatically assign a value to the constant for use in the shader. This will contain a copy of the current projection matrix used by the current viewport.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.IShaderRenderer.HasSpriteImage
member.summary: Property to return whether a sprite image is available in the shader.
member.remarks:
This shader constant should be represented in the shader as: Texture _spriteImage. If this constant is found, this value will return TRUE.
If this is available the library will automatically assign a value to the constant for use in the shader. This will typically be the current image used by a sprite or a series of sprites (if using the same image).

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.Internal.IDeviceStateObject
member.summary: Interface for objects so they can handle device resets and loss.
member.remarks: When the app is in fullscreen mode, a task switch will cause the device to be put into a lost state. Some resources (e.g. resources created in D3DPOOL_DEFAULT) will end up being lost as well, and we will need a way to release these objects and restore them when necessary. Objects should only implement this interface when a device loss/reset affects the resources contained within the object.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Internal.IDeviceStateObject.DeviceLost
member.summary: Function called when the device is in a lost state.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Internal.IDeviceStateObject.DeviceReset
member.summary: Function called when the device is reset.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Internal.IDeviceStateObject.ForceRelease
member.summary: Function to force the loss of the objects data.

member.summary: Constructor.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderTechnique.GorgonLibrary#Graphics#IShaderRenderer#GetDefinedConstants
member.summary: Function to retrieve the pre-defined constant parameters from a shader.
member.remarks:
A shader can contain pre-defined constant values that the library will update automatically. This is done to cut down on some redundant code that the user will typically always have to perform when calling a shader. For example, the user may have 3 shaders and each time a shader is used the current sprite image would have to be set by the user each time the image changed for each sprite. Additionally, passing the transformations (i.e. rotation, scaling and translation) to the shader is also more work than it needs to be.
To use this "default" functionality your shader will have to implement one of these constants:
Constant type and name Description
float4x4 _projectionMatrix The current projection matrix defined by the current Viewport. Use this to transform vertices in a vertex shader into screen space.
Texture _spriteImage This is the currently active image (at index 0 in the texture stage) for a given Sprite or series of sprites.
The constants are case sensitive and as such must be declared exactly as shown in the table above with the leading underscore character. If the constant is not named properly it will not be used as a default.
To test whether the default constants are available, check the return value of HasProjectionMatrix or HasSpriteImage and if these properties return TRUE, then the constant has been implemented.
This function is meant to be called internally by the shader.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderTechnique.GetDefinedParameter(GorgonLibrary.Graphics.PredefinedShaderConstants)
member.summary: Function to return the parameter associated with the predefiend constant.
member.remarks:
The function will return the associated parameter object for a given pre-defined constant. The constant should be defined in the shader as one of:
Constant type and name Description
float4x4 _projectionMatrix The current projection matrix defined by the current Viewport. Use this to transform vertices in a vertex shader into screen space.
Texture _spriteImage This is the currently active image (at index 0 in the texture stage) for a given Sprite or series of sprites.

member.summary: Function to begin the rendering with the shader.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderTechnique.HasProjectionMatrix
member.summary: Property to return whether a projection matrix is available in the shader.
member.remarks:
This shader constant should be represented in the shader as: float4x4 _projectionMatrix. If this constant is found, this value will return TRUE.
If this is available the library will automatically assign a value to the constant for use in the shader. This will contain a copy of the current projection matrix used by the current viewport.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderTechnique.HasSpriteImage
member.summary: Property to return whether a sprite image is available in the shader.
member.remarks:
This shader constant should be represented in the shader as: Texture _spriteImage. If this constant is found, this value will return TRUE.
If this is available the library will automatically assign a value to the constant for use in the shader. This will typically be the current image used by a sprite or a series of sprites (if using the same image).

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.StaticTextSprite
member.summary: Object representing a static text sprite.
member.remarks:
This sprite type is used optimize text display by keeping the text static. Using dynamic text in this object will greatly hinder performance.
This object is now obsolete and should not be used. It will be removed in the next version. Please use the Batch object instead.

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.Renderable
member.summary: Object representing a renderable object.

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.IAnimated
member.summary: An interface to expose methods for animated objects.
member.remarks: All objects that are meant to be animated using the Gorgon animation interface have to implement IAnimated.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.IAnimated.ApplyAnimations
member.summary: Function to apply the current time in an animation to the objects animated properties.
member.remarks: This function will do the actual work of updating the properties (marked with the Animated attribute). It does this by applying the values at the current interpolated (or actual depending on time) key frame to the property that's bound to the track.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.IAnimated.Animations
member.summary: Property to return a list of animations attached to the object.

member.summary: Function to start the rendering process.
member.param: TRUE to flush the contents of the child renderable buffers immediately after rendering is complete, FALSE to hold the contents until the end of frame or state change.
member.remarks: Setting flush to TRUE can slow the rendering process down significantly, only use when absolutely necessary.

member.remarks: Setting flush to TRUE can slow the rendering process down significantly, only use when absolutely necessary.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.FXShader.GetShaderFunction(System.String,System.String,GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderCompileOptions)
member.summary: Function to retrieve a shader function.
member.param: Compilation options for the shader function.
member.returns: The extracted function from the shader.
member.remarks:
The shaderTarget parameter expects one of the following:
Target valueDescription
ps_major_minorPixel shader, where major is the major version number and minor is the minor version number (or letter).
vs_major_minorVertex shader, where major is the major version number and minor is the minor version number (or letter).
tx_1_0Texture shader 1.0.
See for more information about the compile time options.

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.Internal.IndexCache`1
member.summary: Index cache system.
member.remarks: This object will store our indices so that we may read them and modify them at any time.

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.Internal.IDataCache`1
member.summary: Interface defining a cache of data.
member.remarks:
This is a common interface for objects that implement data caching, such as vertex cache or index cache. The implementor object will use this to keep a copy of object data in memory for update before sending to a destination buffer (e.g. a VertexBuffer).
While it is possible to read data back from a vertex/index buffer, it is complex and not a recommended procedure for performance reasons.
Objects that implement this interface should have a buffer of data that will receive the contents of the cache. This keeps the cache atomic ensuring that we either get the data to its destination or not at all.
The usefulness of this type of object is apparent when one needs to update a batch of vertices (e.g. software skinning) and send those to a write-only buffer. This will avoid the overhead of having to open the vertex buffer for reading (if it's even allowed to do so), read the data and modify it, then write the data back to the buffer.
Note that there is a performance penalty in that your data size will be larger since it has to hold a seperate copy of the data.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Internal.IDataCache`1.Update(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Function to update the necessary buffers with the current information held in the cache.
member.remarks: This function is used to send the data to the destination buffer(s).
member.param: TRUE if this is being called due to a device restoration, FALSE if not.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Internal.IDataCache`1.Release
member.summary: Function to release the underlying data buffers.
member.remarks:
Use this function to clear out any of the destination data buffers.
Use this with care as it will invalidate any data buffers that are being referenced elsewhere.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Internal.IDataCache`1.WriteData(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,`0[])
member.summary: Function to write data to the cache.
member.param: Start of the data in the source array of data.
Start in the destination buffer to write at.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Internal.IDataCache`1.Count
member.summary: Property to set or return the number of items within the cache.
member.remarks:
Use this to set the size of the data cache (size is the number of elements, e.g. vertices, and NOT bytes).
For a vertex cache, which will have multiple streams, this will represent the number of vertices, and not the exact size of the stream.
member.value: An integer containing a total count of the items within the cache.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Internal.IDataCache`1.NeedsUpdate
member.summary: Read only property to determine if the underlying buffers need to be updated.
member.value: Returns TRUE if an update is necessary, FALSE if not.

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.BaseDictionaryCollection`1
member.summary: An abstract class representing a hash table of objects.
member.remarks:
This was designed as a point of convenience to take some of the annoyance out of inheriting a hash table.
This class provides a simplified method of inheriting a basic list collection. It holds no benefit over the System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary object, which it uses internally.
This class, like the other collection classes, implements the IEnumerable interface already to return an iterator interface for enumeration.

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.Internal.VertexBuffer
member.summary: Object to hold vertex data.
member.remarks: A vertex buffer can be used to batch up vertex data to send to the card as a packet of vertex information. This will allow for faster rendering, as the fewer DrawPrimitive statements you have, the better. Since Direct3D implicitly uses Vertex Buffers, we should as well. For anyone who wants to port this to OpenGL: it'd be interesting to see how much VBOs differ from Vertex Buffers.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderPass.GorgonLibrary#Graphics#IShaderRenderer#GetDefinedConstants
member.summary: Function to retrieve the pre-defined constant parameters from a shader.
member.remarks:
A shader can contain pre-defined constant values that the library will update automatically. This is done to cut down on some redundant code that the user will typically always have to perform when calling a shader. For example, the user may have 3 shaders and each time a shader is used the current sprite image would have to be set by the user each time the image changed for each sprite. Additionally, passing the transformations (i.e. rotation, scaling and translation) to the shader is also more work than it needs to be.
To use this "default" functionality your shader will have to implement one of these constants:
Constant type and name Description
float4x4 _projectionMatrix The current projection matrix defined by the current Viewport. Use this to transform vertices in a vertex shader into screen space.
Texture _spriteImage This is the currently active image (at index 0 in the texture stage) for a given Sprite or series of sprites.
The constants are case sensitive and as such must be declared exactly as shown in the table above with the leading underscore character. If the constant is not named properly it will not be used as a default.
To test whether the default constants are available, check the return value of HasProjectionMatrix or HasSpriteImage and if these properties return TRUE, then the constant has been implemented.
This function is meant to be called internally by the shader.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderPass.GetDefinedParameter(GorgonLibrary.Graphics.PredefinedShaderConstants)
member.summary: Function to return the parameter associated with the predefiend constant.
member.remarks:
The function will return the associated parameter object for a given pre-defined constant. The constant should be defined in the shader as one of:
Constant type and name Description
float4x4 _projectionMatrix The current projection matrix defined by the current Viewport. Use this to transform vertices in a vertex shader into screen space.
Texture _spriteImage This is the currently active image (at index 0 in the texture stage) for a given Sprite or series of sprites.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderPass.Owner
member.summary: Property to return the owning technique for this pass.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderPass.PassIndex
member.summary: Property to return the index of the shader pass.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderPass.HasProjectionMatrix
member.summary: Property to return whether a projection matrix is available in the shader.
member.remarks:
This shader constant should be represented in the shader as: float4x4 _projectionMatrix. If this constant is found, this value will return TRUE.
If this is available the library will automatically assign a value to the constant for use in the shader. This will contain a copy of the current projection matrix used by the current viewport.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderPass.HasSpriteImage
member.summary: Property to return whether a sprite image is available in the shader.
member.remarks:
This shader constant should be represented in the shader as: Texture _spriteImage. If this constant is found, this value will return TRUE.
If this is available the library will automatically assign a value to the constant for use in the shader. This will typically be the current image used by a sprite or a series of sprites (if using the same image).

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.DualShader.PixelShader
member.summary: Property to set or return the pixel shader to use.
member.remarks: The user should try and ensure the pixel and vertex shaders are the same version, the default shader will automatically default to the highest version supported by DirectX 9 and the video card. If there's a version mismatch, for example, a vs_2_0 vertex shader and a ps_3_0 shader probably won't work as expected.

member.summary: Property to set or return the vertex shader to use.
member.remarks: The user should try and ensure the pixel and vertex shaders are the same version, the default shader will automatically default to the highest version supported by DirectX 9 and the video card. If there's a version mismatch, for example, a vs_2_0 vertex shader and a ps_3_0 shader probably won't work as expected.

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.PredefinedShaderConstants
member.summary: A list of predefined shader constants.
member.remarks:
The shader constants presented here reflect these values in a given shader:
Constant type and name Description
float4x4 _projectionMatrix The current projection matrix defined by the current Viewport. Use this to transform vertices in a vertex shader into screen space.
Texture _spriteImage This is the currently active image (at index 0 in the texture stage) for a given Sprite or series of sprites.

member.summary: A projection matrix used to transform a vertex into screen space.

member.summary: The currently active sprite image at stage 0.

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.Internal.D3DObjects
member.summary: Object used to interface to internal Gorgon D3D objects.
member.remarks:
This is meant for plug-in developers to use as an entry point to gain full access to Gorgon's D3D internals (i.e. if a developer wanted to merge 3D stuff with Gorgon, they'd use this class to gain access to everything).
Since this is strictly for plug-ins, this class can only be accessed from the PlugInEntryPoint superclass as the protected method GetD3DObjects().
BE VERY CAREFUL WITH THIS OBJECT! It cannot be stressed enough, you will be messing with the guts of Gorgon and as such you can easily cause it to crash by doing something wrong.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.RenderImage.Blit(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Drawing.Color,GorgonLibrary.Graphics.BlitterSizeMode)
member.summary: Function to draw this render image to the current render target.
member.param: Color to modulate with the image.
Mode to define how to handle dimensions that are smaller/larger than the image.
member.remarks:
Mode is used to either crop or scale the image when the dimensions are larger or smaller than the source image. It can be one of:
ScaleScale the image up or down to match the width and height parameters.
CropClip the image if it's larger than the width and height passed. If the image is smaller, then the image will be handled according to the HorizontalWrapMode or the VerticalWrapMode.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.RenderImage.GetImageData(System.Drawing.Rectangle)
member.summary: Function to retrieve the underlying image data for direct access.
member.returns: An Image.ImageLockBox which contains the direct access to the underlying image.
member.remarks: This function acts as a means of direct image maniuplation. This means while the user is given direct control over the contents of the image the system will provide NO support for any data read/written to the lock area. There will be no image resizing, no color conversion, the user will be on their own and must be aware of the image format.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.RenderImage.GetImageData
member.summary: Function to retrieve the underlying image data for direct access.
member.returns: An Image.ImageLockBox which contains the direct access to the underlying image.
member.remarks:
This function acts as a means of direct image maniuplation. This means while the user is given direct control over the contents of the image the system will provide NO support for any data read/written to the lock area. There will be no image resizing, no color conversion, the user will be on their own and must be aware of the image format.
This overload of the function will lock the entire image for reading/writing.

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.Internal.BufferUsages
member.summary: Enumeration for buffer usage types.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Internal.BufferUsages.Static
member.summary: Static buffers. A static buffer should not be modified very often or at all if possible. These buffers are typically stored in video RAM.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Internal.BufferUsages.Dynamic
member.summary: Make a dynamic buffer, good for when there's going to be frequent changes to the buffer.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Internal.BufferUsages.WriteOnly
member.summary: An optimization to make the buffer write only, reading from a buffer with writeonly set will result in failure.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Internal.BufferUsages.ForceSoftware
member.summary: Force this buffer into standard memory as opposed to video RAM.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Internal.BufferUsages.UseSystemMemory
member.summary: Put this buffer into system memory. This buffer will be inaccessable to Direct3D and can only be used as storage.

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.Internal.BufferLockFlags
member.summary: Flags used for buffer locking.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Internal.BufferLockFlags.Normal
member.summary: No locking flags, used with static buffers.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Internal.BufferLockFlags.NoOverwrite
member.summary: This flag will guarantee that we will not overwrite any data in the buffer and allow us to continue rendering.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Internal.BufferLockFlags.Discard
member.summary: This flag will discard the contents of the buffer and returns a new pointer to a memory area to avoid stalls. Only to be used on dynamic buffers.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Internal.BufferLockFlags.ReadOnly
member.summary: This flag will make the buffer read only, and give certain optimizations.

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.Internal.IndexBufferType
member.summary: Flags for index buffer types.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Internal.IndexBufferType.Index16
member.summary: Use 16 bit indices.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Internal.IndexBufferType.Index32
member.summary: Use 32 bit indices.

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.Internal.BufferTypes
member.summary: Enumeration containing the types of buffers.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Internal.BufferTypes.Vertex
member.summary: Vertex buffer.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Internal.BufferTypes.Index
member.summary: Index buffer.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Internal.BufferTypes.Image
member.summary: Image buffer.

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.AnimationState
member.summary: Animation states.
member.remarks: These states describe if an animation can have its time advanced or not.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.AnimationState.Playing
member.summary: Animation is currently in a play state and is ready to have its time position advanced.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.AnimationState.Stopped
member.summary: Animation is currently in a stopped state and changes to its time position will be ignored.

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.Animation
member.summary: An animation object will contain animation data that can be applied to a animation capable object.
member.remarks:
Animations can be used to move a sprite, change its color over time, or even flip between individual frames.
An animation is composed of several tracks, which represent a specific type of animation. Currently there are 3 tracks:
Type Description
Color Used to animate the color and alpha related properties of an animated object.
Frame Used to flip between frames of animation.
Transformation Used to apply move, scale or rotate transformations to the animated object.

member.summary: Function to retrieve the range values for the property.
member.param: Property to retrieve the range from.

member.summary: Function to return whether to round the data for the values or not.
member.returns: TRUE to round, FALSE to ignore.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.Animation.ValueCanBeDragged(System.Reflection.PropertyInfo)
member.summary: Function to return whether the editor can drag the data values or not with the mouse.
member.returns: TRUE to drag, FALSE to ignore.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.Animation.CreateAnimation(System.String,System.Single)
member.summary: Function to create a new animation object.
member.param: Length of the animation in milliseconds.
member.remarks:
This function is meant to be overridden in a derived class to return a custom animation object type.
This function is meant to only to be used internally by the Clone method.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.Animation.OnAnimationTrackDefine(System.Object,GorgonLibrary.Graphics.AnimationTrackDefineEventArgs)
member.summary: Function called when the animation needs to define an unknown track type.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.Animation.SetOwner(GorgonLibrary.Graphics.IAnimated)
member.summary: Function to set the owner for this animation.
member.remarks:
This function will enumerate the properties on the object that are marked with the Animated attribute and will create tracks for each of the properties. All keys assigned to those tracks will ultimately update the properties assigned to the tracks.
The types of the tracks correspond with the type value passed to the Animated attribute.
Calling this function will wipe out any keys and/or tracks in the animation.

member.param: New object that will own this animation.
member.returns: A new object that is a copy of this instance.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.Image.Blit(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Drawing.Color,GorgonLibrary.Graphics.BlitterSizeMode)
member.summary: Function to blit this image to the current render target.
member.param: Color to modulate with the image.
Mode to define how to handle dimensions that are smaller/larger than the image.
member.remarks:
Mode is used to either crop or scale the image when the dimensions are larger or smaller than the source image. It can be one of:
ScaleScale the image up or down to match the width and height parameters.
CropClip the image if it's larger than the width and height passed. If the image is smaller, then the image will be handled according to the Gorgon.CurrentRenderTarget.HorizontalWrapMode or the Gorgon.CurrentRenderTarget.VerticalWrapMode.

member.summary: Function to unlock the image.

member.summary: Function to lock an image.
member.param: TRUE to discard the data, FALSE to leave alone.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.Image.ImageLockBox.Read(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Function to read data directly from the lock stream.
member.param: Buffer to fill with data from the lock stream.
member.remarks:
This function depends on where the stream pointer is positioned. You can adjust the position in the lock stream by using the LockPosition property.
Unlike ReadRegion, this function will NOT respect the region specified in the lock. The user will be responsible for keeping the data within the region.

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.PlugIns.PlugInFactory
member.summary: Object to repesent a list of plugins.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.PlugIns.PlugInFactory.SetComparisonKey(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Function to set the key to use for comparison with the assembly public key.
member.param: An array of bytes containing the data for the public key to use in a comparison or NULL.
member.remarks:
This function allows us to compare the public key for a specific plug-in against what we have stored here. With this we can filter plug-ins that are not signed by the owner of the public key. This adds a small measure of security.
Passing NULL as the key will allow any signed assembly plug-in to load.

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.BaseDynamicArray`1
member.summary: An abstract class for representing a dynamic array of objects.
member.remarks:
This was designed as a point of convenience to take some of the annoyance out of inheriting a collection.
This class provides a simplified method of inheriting a basic list collection. It holds no benefit over the System.Collections.Generic.List object, which it uses internally.
This class, like the other collection classes, implements the IEnumerable interface already to return an iterator interface for enumeration.

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.Internal.DeviceStateList
member.summary: Class to handle device resets and loss.
member.remarks: When the app is in fullscreen mode, a task switch will cause the device to be put into a lost state. Some resources (e.g. resources created in D3DPOOL_DEFAULT) will end up being lost as well, and we will need a way to release these objects and restore them when necessary. This class will contain all objects that can be lost and reset when such the above situation occours. This class should only be used internally and never called upon by the calling application.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.InputDevices.Joystick.POVCount
member.summary: Property to return the number of POV hats.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.InputDevices.Joystick.DeadZone
member.summary: Property to return the dead zone range.
member.remarks:
The dead zone should be within the range of the same axis. That is, if the axis range is between 0..32767, then the dead zone range should be within 0..32767. Likewise if the axis has a range of -32767..32767 then the dead zone value should correspond to the range of -32767..32767.
Please note that by setting the dead zone to the exact size of the axis range the joystick will not register any movement because the entire range is considered 'dead'.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.InputDevices.Joystick.Axes
member.summary: Property to return a value for an axis.
member.remarks: This is affected by the DeadZone property. Any values that fall within the dead zone range are ignored and as such only the mid-point of the axis range will be returned (center position of the axis).

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.InputDevices.Joystick.AxisDirection
member.summary: Property to return the direction that an axis is pointed towards.
member.remarks: This is affected by the DeadZone property. If the axis position is within the dead-zone range only the JoystickDirections.Center position is returned.

member.summary: Property to return the point of view values.

member.remarks: This is affected by the DeadZone property. Any values that fall within the dead zone range are ignored and as such only the mid-point of the X axis range will be returned (center position of the axis).

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.InputDevices.Joystick.Y
member.summary: Property to return the y coordinate for the joystick.
member.remarks: This is affected by the DeadZone property. Any values that fall within the dead zone range are ignored and as such only the mid-point of the Y axis range will be returned (center position of the axis).

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.Internal.Native.Win32API
member.summary: Static class for Native Win32 methods and corresponding structures.
member.remarks:
This is a grouping of any Windows API calls used by Gorgon.
This list is by no means complete. The Win32 API is just massive and would probably take a lifetime to map.
These calls are considered "unsafe" and thus should be used with care. If you don't know how to use a function, or why you want it, you probably don't need to use them.
Please note that a lot of the enumerators/structures have slightly different names than their Win32 counterparts. This was done for the sake of readability. This does NOT affect their results or their effect on the results of their related functionality.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Internal.Native.Win32API.ShowCursor(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Function to set the visibility of the mouse cursor.
member.param: TRUE to show, FALSE to hide.
member.returns: -1 if no mouse is installed, 0 or greater for the number of times this function has been called with TRUE.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Internal.Native.Win32API.PeekMessage(GorgonLibrary.Internal.Native.MSG@,System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Int32,GorgonLibrary.Internal.Native.PeekMessageFlags)
member.summary: Function to process window messages.
member.remarks: See the MSDN documentation for a detailed description.
member.param: Window to retrieve messages from, FALSE for all.
member.returns: TRUE if messages are ready for processing, FALSE if not.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Internal.Native.Win32API.TranslateMessage(GorgonLibrary.Internal.Native.MSG@)
member.summary: Function to translate windows messages.
member.returns: TRUE if successful, FALSE if not.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Internal.Native.Win32API.DispatchMessage(GorgonLibrary.Internal.Native.MSG@)
member.summary: Function to dispatch windows messages.
member.returns: TRUE if successful, FALSE if not.

member.summary: Function to return the frequency of the high precision timer.
member.remarks: See the MSDN documentation for a detailed description.
member.returns: TRUE if system supports high precision timing, FALSE if not.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Internal.Native.Win32API.QueryPerformanceCounter(System.Int64@)
member.summary: Function to return the time from a high resolution timer.
member.remarks: See the MSDN documentation for a detailed description.
member.returns: TRUE if system supports high precision timing, FALSE if not.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Internal.Native.Win32API.timeGetTime
member.summary: Function to return time from a medium precision timer.
member.remarks:
See the MSDN documentation for a detailed description.
This timer is of lower precision than the high precision timers, do not use unless your system does not support high resolution timers.

member.summary: Function to start a timing session.

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderCompileOptions
member.summary: Enumeration containing shader compilation flags.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderCompileOptions.None
member.summary: No optimization or options.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderCompileOptions.Debug
member.summary: Debug mode.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderCompileOptions.SkipValidation
member.summary: Instruct the compiler to skip optimization steps during code generation. Unless you are trying to isolate a problem in your code and you suspect the compiler, using this option is not recommended.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderCompileOptions.SkipOptimization
member.summary: Do not validate the generated code against known capabilities and constraints. This option is recommended only when compiling shaders that are known to work (that is, shaders that have compiled before without this option). Shaders are always validated by the runtime before they are set to the device.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderCompileOptions.PackMatrixRowMajor
member.summary: Unless explicitly specified, matrices will be packed in row-major order (each vector will be in a single row) when passed to or from the shader.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderCompileOptions.PackMatrixColumnMajor
member.summary: Unless explicitly specified, matrices will be packed in column-major order (each vector will be in a single column) when passed to and from the shader. This is generally more efficient because it allows vector-matrix multiplication to be performed using a series of dot products.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderCompileOptions.PartialPrecision
member.summary: Force all computations in the resulting shader to occur at partial precision This may result in faster evaluation of shaders on some hardware.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderCompileOptions.ForceVSSoftwareNoOpt
member.summary: Force the compiler to compile against the next highest available software target for vertex shaders. This flag also turns optimizations off and debugging on.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderCompileOptions.ForcePSSoftwareNoOpt
member.summary: Force the compiler to compile against the next highest available software target for pixel shaders. This flag also turns optimizations off and debugging on.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderCompileOptions.NoPreshader
member.summary: Disables preshaders. The compiler will not pull out static expressions for evaluation on the host CPU. Additionally, the compiler will not loft any expressions when compiling stand-alone functions.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderCompileOptions.AvoidFlowControl
member.summary: This is a hint to the compiler to avoid using flow-control instructions.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderCompileOptions.PreferFlowControl
member.summary: This is a hint to the compiler to prefer using flow-control instructions.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderCompileOptions.IeeeStrictness
member.summary: Disable optimizations that may cause the output of a compiled shader program to differ from the output of a program compiled with the DirectX 9 shader compiler due to small precision erros in floating point math.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderCompileOptions.OptimizationLevel0
member.summary: Lowest optimization level. May produce slower code but will do so more quickly. This may be useful in a highly iterative shader development cycle.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderCompileOptions.OptimizationLevel3
member.summary: Highest optimization level. Will produce best possible code but may take significantly longer to do so. This will be useful for final builds of an application where performance is the most important factor.

member.name: F:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ShaderCompileOptions.OptimizationLevel2
member.summary: Second highest optimization level.

member.summary: Constructor.

member.summary: Property to return the time delta between this and the last frame.

member.summary: Current animation time.

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.AnimationTrackDefineHandler
member.summary: Event handler used when the time has been updated for an animation frame.
member.remarks: When a property is marked as animated, and its type is unknown to the animation system (e.g. a custom object or value type) we can still animate that property if we define the track type. This event allows us to pass back a new instance of the track type to the animation and will allow the user to customize how to handle that particular type within an animation.

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.AnimationTrackDefineEventArgs
member.summary: Event arguments for animation track definitions.
member.remarks: When a property is marked as animated, and its type is unknown to the animation system (e.g. a custom object or value type) we can still animate that property if we define the track type. This event allows us to pass back a new instance of the track type to the animation and will allow the user to customize how to handle that particular type within an animation.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.AnimationTrackDefineEventArgs.#ctor(System.String,System.Type)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: Name of the property being animated.
Type of the data represented by the track.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.AnimationTrackDefineEventArgs.Track
member.summary: Property to set or return the track type.

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.ImageType
member.summary: Enumeration containing the types of images we can create.
member.remarks:
The value is used internally by Gorgon and should not be used when creating an image, however it can be used when validating an image format with Driver.ValidImageFormat or Image.ValidateFormat.
The value will ensure the image is dynamic whether the Driver.SupportDynamicTextures property is TRUE or FALSE. If the hardware supports dynamic textures then Gorgon will make use of it, otherwise the image will be a normal image placed in the default pool.

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.Batch
member.summary: A batch of sprites to be statically renderered.
member.remarks:
The purpose of this object is to quickly render multiple sprites in one pass. In the immediate type model used by the Sprite object the buffer where the sprites are stored is flushed when a change (image change, state change, etc...) occurs. For example, if you draw multiple sprites and one of those sprites has an image that is different from the previous sprites, the buffer will flush all the previous sprites to the render target. Then the process starts over with an empty buffer. This has advantages, but sometimes this will slow down the rendering process.
Batched sprites however will take multiple sprite objects and store them into a buffer and will flush that buffer only when the render target is updated. This has the advantage of being able to draw all the sprites in one shot and those sprites will be "cached" each time the batch is drawn so that the buffers that store the sprites never need to be updated (unless a change is made).
There is a caveat with this approach: The sprites cannot move or be animated in any way. This means that the sprites stored are "snapshots" of the sprite at a given time and will not be affected by any transformations made after the fact. The sprites will update when the batch is invalidated and rebuilt however, but this process is slow and is not recommended for real time use. The sprites in the batch will be affected by the batch transforms however, but all the sprites will be effected as a single entity and not individually.
The best usage of this object is in a "map" scenario, where the map is a tile map and the sprites that compose the map as tiles are blitted in one shot.

member.name: T:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon
member.summary: The primary interface into gorgon.
member.remarks:
This interface handles the initialization of Gorgon from internal data structures to the video mode to be used. Users should call Gorgon.Initialize before doing anything and call Gorgon.Terminate when finished.
This static class is used to change the global states of objects such as a global rendering setting to which render target is current. It will also control the execution and rendering flow for the application.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.IsRenderTargetActive(GorgonLibrary.Graphics.RenderTarget)
member.summary: Function to determine if a render target is active.
member.returns: TRUE if the render target is active, FALSE if not.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.SetAdditionalRenderTarget(System.Int32,GorgonLibrary.Graphics.RenderTarget)
member.summary: Function to set additional render targets.
member.param: A render target to bind to the index.
member.remarks:
This will allow the user to set more than one render target at a time for simultaneous rendering. Please note that using multiple render targets is only supported when using shaders.
An index of 0 will set the current primary render target which is identical to using Gorgon.CurrentRenderTarget.
There are some limitations to setting multiple render targets: The render targets should have the same width and height. They can use a different image format but the image formats of the targets must have the same bit count. This restriction is lifted for devices that have Driver.SupportMRTIndepenedentBitDepths set to true.
If Driver.SupportMRTPostPixelShaderBlending is true then post pixel shader blending operations can be performed by the video card. However, if it is supported, the render target must queried to see if it will support post pixel shader blending operations via the RenderTarget.IsValidForMRTPostPixelShaderBlending property.
Passing NULL (Nothing in Visual Basic) with an index of 0 will set the render target to the Gorgon.Screen render target.
member.exception: Thrown when Gorgon.Initialize has not been called, Gorgon.SetMode wasn't called or the target cannot be bound.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.GetAdditionalRenderTarget(System.Int32)
member.summary: Function to return an additional render target from the active render target list.
member.returns: The render target at the specified index.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.CloseMode
member.summary: Function to close the currently active video mode.
member.remarks: Some resources may have to be re-loaded or re-created when this function is called and another call to SetMode is made.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.SetMode(System.Windows.Forms.Control,System.Int32,System.Int32,GorgonLibrary.BackBufferFormats,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Int32,GorgonLibrary.VSyncIntervals)
member.summary: Function to set the video mode and primary rendering window.
member.remarks:
When this function is successful it will create a new PrimaryRenderWindow and assign it to the Screen property, and will bind the primary render target to its owner control.
If the client size of the owning control does not match the width and height passed in to the function and the windowed parameter is TRUE, and the owning control is a Form, then the client size of the form will be adjusted to match that of the width and height passed in. If the owning control is not a form, then the width and height will adjusted to the client size of the owning control.
When in windowed mode, the vsync parameter and refresh rate parameter will be ignored.
When going to full screen mode the width and height must match one of the video modes listed in the CurrentDriver.VideoModes list. If not, an exception will be thrown.
member.param: Control that will be bound to the PrimaryRenderWindow and will be the initial canvas to receive drawing commands.
Buffer format for the video mode.
TRUE to use windowed mode, FALSE to go fullscreen.
TRUE to create a depth buffer, FALSE to not create.
TRUE to create a stencil buffer, FALSE to not create.
Refresh rate of the video mode.
member.exception: Thrown when NULL is passed in for the owner parameter.
Thrown when a video device object could not be created.

Thrown when full screen mode is chosen and the video mode does not match a video mode on the CurrentDriver.VideoModes list. Can also be thrown if the desktop video mode does not support hardware acceleration.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.SetMode(System.Windows.Forms.Control,System.Int32,System.Int32,GorgonLibrary.BackBufferFormats,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Int32)

If the owning control is not a form, then the width and height will adjusted to the client size of the owning control.
When in windowed mode, the vsync parameter and refresh rate parameter will be ignored.
When going to full screen mode the width and height must match one of the video modes listed in the CurrentDriver.VideoModes list. If not, an exception will be thrown.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.SetMode(System.Windows.Forms.Control)
member.summary: Function to set the video mode and primary rendering window.
member.remarks:
When this function is successful it will create a new PrimaryRenderWindow and assign it to the Screen property, and will bind the primary render target to its owner control.
In this overload of the function the width and height of the video mode are set to the client width and height of the owner control. The video mode will also be forced into windowed mode and the format will be set to the desktop video mode format.

member.summary: Event fired when a driver is currently being changed.

member.name: E:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.DeviceReset
member.summary: Event fired when the device has been reset from a lost state.
member.remarks:
A number of events can put the device into a lost state. For example, resizing the control that is bound to the primary render window.
Some objects will need to be re-created during a device loss/reset event. In this event you put in the code to rebuild the object that needs to be reset.

member.name: E:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.DeviceLost
member.summary: Event fired when the device has been put into a lost state.
member.remarks:
A number of events can put the device into a lost state. For example, resizing the control that is bound to the primary render window.
Some objects will need to be re-created during a device loss/reset event. In this event you put in clean up code to remove data for objects that need to be reset.

member.name: E:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.Idle
member.summary: Event fired when rendering begins for a new frame.
member.remarks: This event is where all the application logic and drawing should take place. It is called once per frame and will return frame statistics to help with things like keeping sprite transformation speed independant of the processor speed.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.AppIdle
member.summary: Property to return if an application is in an idle state or not.

member.summary: Property to set or return the renderer interface.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.Platform

member.remarks: When the library is compiled for 64-bit processors, then this will read x64, otherwise it'll be x86. If the platform cannot be determined it will return unknown.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.FrameStatsTextColor
member.summary: Property to set or return the frame statistics text color.
member.remarks: This only applies if FrameStatsVisible is TRUE.
member.value: The color of the text for the frame statistics.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.FastResize
member.summary: Property to set or return whether or not the resizing the window will reset the display.
member.remarks:
When TRUE, the contents of the window client area will be stretched to match the size of the resized client area. However, no actual change to the video mode will be made. If it was set to 640x480 before the resizing, the screen dimensions after resizing the window will still be 640x480. This will produce a blurry looking image when resized larger than the previous size. When fast resizing is enabled, all resources are preserved because there was no actual change to the video device.
If FALSE, then the device will undergo a reset operation and the video mode will be adjusted to match the new client size of the owning control/window. This will keep the sharpness of the rendered image regardless of the client size of the control/window. The caveat is that some resources will need to be re-loaded/re-created when the device reset occurs. This is the exact behaviour of the system when a full screen application loses and regains focus. Furthermore, window resizing will be much slower (hence the "Fast" portion of FastResize).
member.value: TRUE will enable a fast resizing, FALSE will disable it.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.LogoVisible
member.summary: Property to set or return whether the logo is shown or not.
member.value: TRUE to show the Gorgon logo in the lower right corner of the screen while rendering, FALSE to hide.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.FrameStatsVisible
member.summary: Property to set or return whether the frame timing data is shown or not.
member.value: TRUE to show the current frame statistics (i.e. Frames Per Second, frame delta time, etc...) in the upper left corner of the screen while rendering. FALSE to hide.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.ClearEachFrame
member.summary: Property to set or return which buffers are cleared per frame.
member.example:
To clear the back buffer and depth buffer, you should specify:
gorgonObject.ClearEachFrame = ClearTargets.BackBuffer | ClearTargets.DepthBuffer;

To clear no buffers:
gorgonObject.ClearEachFrame = ClearTargets.None;
member.remarks:
All the ClearTargets fields are inclusive, except the ClearTargets.None. Setting the field to None will tell the system that no buffers are to be cleared.
Clearing the buffer(s) each frame can be an expensive process, especially on computers not equipped with the latest and greatest hardware. Thus, for optimization, it's best to clear only what you need. If you aren't making use of your stencil buffer, then don't bother to clear it each frame and so forth.
member.value:
Set to one or a combination of the ClearTargets fields to tell the system which buffers should be cleared each frame.
The property can be set to one or more of:
Buffer type. Action.
None Don't clear any buffers. This flag cannot be used in conjunction with any of the other flags.
BackBuffer Clear the back buffer.
DepthBuffer Clear the depth buffer.
StencilBuffer Clear the stencil buffer.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.GlobalStateSettings
member.summary: Property to return the render state cache for renderables.
member.remarks: Changing the states in this property will result in that state being applied to all renderable objects. The exception to this is when the state has been changed directly on the renderable object itself.
member.exception: Thrown when Gorgon.Initialize() has not been called.
member.value: A list of global settings that sprites and text sprites will use as initial and inherited values.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.CurrentClippingViewport
member.summary: Property to set or return the currently active clipping viewport.
member.remarks:
Use this property to clip any drawing outside of the rectangle region specified.
Setting this property to NULL will set the clipping viewport dimensions to the size of the current render target dimensions.
member.value: A rectangular region that defines what area of the screen (or other render target) to update.
member.exception: Thrown when Gorgon.Initialize() has not been called.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.CurrentVideoMode
member.summary: Property to return information about the current video mode.
member.remarks: If a video mode has not been set, and Gorgon.Initialize() has been called, then the current desktop video mode is returned instead.
member.value: The currently active video mode information.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.CurrentShader
member.summary: Property to set or return the currently active shader.
member.remarks: Use this to apply a shader to the rendering pass. You can apply either a , or a . When applying a shader there's a very small performance hit on the first pass of rendering as it attempts to locate the first valid shader technique.
member.value: A shader renderer output to apply to the scene when rendering.
member.exception:
Thrown when Gorgon.Initialize() has not been called.
Thrown when Gorgon.SetMode() has not been called.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.CurrentRenderTarget
member.summary: Property to set or return the currently active render target.
member.remarks:
Use this to change where sprites, primitives and text will be drawn. This will allow for objects to be drawn off-screen or into another control that's bound with a RenderWindow.
Set this property to NULL to continue drawing to the primary screen.
Please note that when the render target is switched the clipping viewport is reset to the size of the render target being assigned.
member.exception:
Thrown when Gorgon.Initialize() has not been called.
Thrown when Gorgon.SetMode() has not been called.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.Screen
member.summary: Property to return the primary rendering window.
member.remarks:
There is only one of these PrimaryRenderWindow objects active at any given time. Other controls that have render targets use RenderWindow objects.
When the primary video mode bound to the control is closed, then all other render targets are automatically destroyed.
member.value: The primary rendering window or the "Screen". This can be any control and is the primary render target that is setup during the SetMode() function. As such, this is the initial render target when a video mode is set.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.DesktopVideoMode
member.summary: Property to return the video mode information for the desktop.
member.value: The desktop video mode information.
member.exception: Thrown when Gorgon.Initialize() has not been called.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.FrameStats
member.summary: Property to return the current frame timing stats.
member.remarks: This is usually used for internal purposes, please use the FrameEventArgs timing information in the Idle event instead.
member.value: Returns a TimingData object containing information about the most current frame statistics.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.IsInitialized
member.summary: Property to return whether the library has been initialized or not.
member.value: TRUE if Initialize() has been called, FALSE if not.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.Log
member.summary: Property to return the logging object.
member.remarks: Usage of this property will require the SharpUtilities library and the SharpUtilities.Utility namespace.
member.value: The internal logging interface used by the library.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.CurrentDriver
member.summary: Property to set or return the currently active driver.
member.remarks:
Setting this property to another driver index will make the video mode reset and all data uploaded to the video card (such as textures) will be destroyed and will have to be reset after the video mode has been set again.
The reason it does this is due to the uncertainty of using multiple video cards: If video card A has only 640x480x16 and video card B has 800x600x32 and 640x480x32, and we are currently using B, then upon switching to A we have to allow the user to change to a video mode that is supported by card A.
After the driver ID is changed, it is up to the client program to determine if the mode is supported and reset to that mode, else set to a default video mode.
You should confirm how many drivers are installed in the system via the Drivers.Count property before setting the driver index.
member.value: This will get/set the current video driver index, which is ranged from 0 to DriverList.Count - 1.
member.exception: Thrown when Gorgon.Initialize() has not been called.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.Drivers
member.summary: Property to return a list of video drivers available for rendering.
member.remarks: If a driver does not have hardware acceleration, it will not be included in the list.
member.value: The list of installed video drivers.
member.exception: Thrown when Gorgon.Initialize() has not been called.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.AllowBackgroundRendering
member.summary: Property to set or return a flag that controls background rendering.
member.remarks:
When this property is set to TRUE the CPU usage will jump to 100% while the application is running. This is because it will continuously update and receive messages from the system while in the background. This may cause the system to slow down (if you have a slow video card/CPU) when background rendering is on.
When the property is set to FALSE, the CPU usage will only be at 100% when the application is in the foreground and will throttle back to 0% when the application is in the background. This is much more efficient, however the drawback is that the application will not update while in the background.
member.value: Setting this to TRUE will allow the engine to render while the window is not in the foreground or minimized. Setting this to FALSE will halt rendering until the window is in the foreground.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.IsRunning
member.summary: Property to return if the app is in a running state or not.
member.remarks: This flag is set to TRUE when the Go() function is called and FALSE when the Stop() function is called.
member.value: TRUE if the application is running, and FALSE if not.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.AllowScreenSaver
member.summary: Property to set or return whether we want to allow a screensaver to run or not.
member.remarks:
When this property is set to TRUE all power management/screen saver functionality will be suspended while the application is running.
Due to an unknown reason (presumably this is for security purposes) in Windows, when the screensaver is set to return to the login/welcome screen after its deactivated the application will NOT suspend the screensaver/power management. There currently is no workaround for this, however if you know of one, send the author an email explaining how to circumvent this.
member.value: Set this property to TRUE if you wish to allow the screensaver/power management to kick in. Set to FALSE if you want to suspend the screensaver/power management.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Gorgon.MinimumFrameTime
member.summary: Property to set or return the minimum amount of time to wait between frames (in milliseconds).
member.example:
The following code will limit the frame rate to 30 FPS:
Gorgon.MinimumFrameTime = PreciseTimer.FpsToMilliseconds(30);
member.remarks:
This can be used as a frame rate limiting mechanism. By stalling for the appropriate number of milliseconds before the frame is rendered the frame rate can be kept at a desired level.
The static function PreciseTimer.FpsToMilliseconds can be used to determine how many milliseconds are required for a particular frame rate.
member.value: This number will pause the renderer for the number of milliseconds requested before rendering the frame. The lowest value that can be set is 0.001.

member.name: M:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.PolygonSprite.PolygonVertexList.AddVertex(GorgonLibrary.Vector3D,GorgonLibrary.Vector2D,System.Drawing.Color)
member.summary: Function to add a vertex to the polygon.
member.param: 3D position of the vertex. The Z value is used to interact with the depth buffer.
The relative coordinate of the image being mapped to the polygon.
The diffuse color of the vertex.
member.returns: The vertex that was added to the polygon.
member.remarks: The parameter is different from that of other objects that use image mapping (e.g. a Sprite). The other objects express their image mapping in absolute image coordinates, that is if a 32x32 image is used then the image is mapped from 0 to 32 for width and/or height. However in this case the image mapping is relative to the image. This means that to map the aforementioned image you would pass 0.0 to 1.0. Where 1.0 is the width or height of our image.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.Font.ResourceCount
member.summary: Property to return the number of resources the font consumes.
member.remarks:
Resources mean the number of backing images that are required to hold the glyphs. Too many images can lead to texture thrashing on the card and really hinder performance. This property will allow the user to monitor how many resources the font is using and allow a chance to adjust by manipulating the or raising the and/or the .
This value should never be less than 1 and ideally only return 1.

member.name: P:GorgonLibrary.Graphics.Font.UserBrush
member.summary: Property to set or return a user defined brush used to paint the font.
member.remarks:
This property will make a clone of the original brush and will use that clone internally.
Please note that the user brush will override any color/gradient settings on the font.
